description: This table summarizes the composition of the PokerBench benchmark dataset.  It shows the number of spots (specific game scenarios) included for both pre-flop and post-flop game stages in the evaluation and training sets.

caption: Table 2: Performance of various pre-trained and fine-tuned LLMs on PokerBench.
description: This table presents the performance of several large language models (LLMs) on the PokerBench benchmark.  It shows the accuracy of both pre-trained and fine-tuned models in terms of Exact Match (EM) and Action Accuracy (AA), broken down by pre-flop and post-flop performance. The models evaluated include GPT-4, ChatGPT 3.5, various Llama models (Llama-3 8B, Llama-3 70B, Llama-2 70B, Llama-2 7B), and the Gemma-2B model.  The results highlight the significant underperformance of even state-of-the-art LLMs in poker compared to other benchmarks, and show the improvement possible with fine-tuning.

content:
CHECKPOINT NAME EM AA
Llama-3-8B 800 58.62 61.32
Llama-3-8B 1600 65.96 69.60
Llama-3-8B 5000 78.26 80.64
caption: Table 3: Selected checkpoints for heads-up games.
description: This table shows the checkpoints of the Llama-3-8B model selected for the heads-up poker games.  The checkpoints are identified by the number of optimization steps during fine-tuning (800, 1600, and 5000). For each checkpoint, the table provides the corresponding EM (Exact Match) and AA (Action Accuracy) scores on the POKERBENCH dataset, indicating the model's performance in terms of both action selection and wager amount accuracy.

content:
GAME WINNER WIN RATE
5000 vs 1600 5000 24.79 bb/100
5000 vs 800 5000 50.88 bb/100
1600 vs 800 1600 34.99 bb/100
caption: Table 4: Results of heads-up games against players 5000, 1600 and 800.
description: This table presents the results of head-to-head poker matches between three different fine-tuned Llama-3-8B models.  These models were checkpoints saved during training, with different numbers of optimization steps completed (800, 1600, and 5000). Each model played 50,000 hands against each of the other two models. The win rate is expressed in big blinds per 100 hands (bb/100). The table demonstrates how a higher score on the POKERBENCH benchmark correlates with a higher win rate in actual gameplay.

content:
GAME STAGE WINNER WIN RATE
Overall GPT-4 22.20 bb/100
Pre-flop 5000 17.80 bb/100
Flop GPT-4 34.97 bb/100
Turn GPT-4 24.04 bb/100
River 5000 18.02 bb/100
caption: Table 5: Results of the 1,000 heads-up games between Player 5000 and GPT-4. As the sample size is limited, the absolute value of win-rate is less meaningful. Instead, we provide a playing style analysis to better understand the models’ performances.
description: This table presents the results of 1000 heads-up poker games between Player 5000 (the fine-tuned Llama-3-8B model with the highest POKERBENCH score) and GPT-4.  Due to the relatively small number of games, the win rates themselves aren't highly statistically significant.  However, the table's main purpose is to offer a qualitative comparison of the two models' playing styles (e.g., aggression, bet sizing) across different stages of the poker hand (pre-flop, flop, turn, river). This analysis helps in understanding the strengths and weaknesses of each model's approach to the game, providing insight beyond just a simple win/loss count.

content:
GAME STAGE ACTION GPT-4 LLAMA
Pre-flop Open-Raises (Percentage) 15.3% 27.3%
Flop + Turn Donking-Bets (Percentage) 25.0% 0.0%
Flop + Turn Bets/Raises (Times/Street) 0.823 0.312
River Bets/Raises (Times/Street) 0.465 0.134
caption: Table 6: Playing Style Summary of GPT-4 vs. Player 5000
description: This table compares the playing styles of GPT-4 and the fine-tuned Llama model (Player 5000) in a heads-up poker game.  It shows the frequency of specific actions (open raises, donking bets, and bets/raises) at different stages of the game (pre-flop, flop/turn, and river). This comparison helps to illustrate why, despite the Llama model's superior performance on the POKERBENCH benchmark, GPT-4 won more hands overall. The differences in action frequencies highlight differing levels of aggression and play style.

content:
Few-Shot Prompt
You are a specialist in playing 6-handed No Limit Texas Holdem. The following will be a game scenario and you need to make the optimal decision.

Here is a game summary:

The small blind is 0.5 chips and the big blind is 1 chips. Everyone started with 100 chips.
The player positions involved in this game are UTG, HJ, CO, BTN, SB, BB.
In this hand, your position is HJ, and your holding is [King of Heart and King of Spade].
Before the flop, HJ raise 2.0, CO raise 6.5, and SB raise 17.5. Assume that all other players that is not mentioned folded.

Now it is your turn to make a move.
To remind you, the current pot size is 27.0 chips, and your holding is [King of Heart and King of Spade].

Decide on an action based on the strength of your hand on this board, your position, and actions before you. Do not explain your answer.
Your optimal action is: all in
caption: Table 7: Example prompt used for few-shot evaluations of pre-trained LLMs. The above example is a prompt for one single spot. In the few-shot scenario, multiple such spots are presented to the model before the query spot is presented.
description: This table shows an example of a prompt used in the few-shot evaluation setting for pre-trained LLMs in the poker experiment.  The example demonstrates a single game scenario presented to the model, requiring the model to make an optimal decision given the hand, player position, bets, and current pot size. In a real few-shot evaluation, the model would receive several such scenarios before being asked to predict the optimal action for a final, unseen scenario.
